reviewText: I was stunned to see this movie is finally out on DVD format.  I have waited years for this film to appear, it deserves a bigger audience.  Like a previous reviewer, I have a number of war films in my collection.  I rate this picture 4 and a half stars.Nick Nolte does a solid job as a former Marine who leaves the war behind him and finds refuge with a head hunter tribe in Borneo.  Through fate and circumstance, he becomes king and leader of his tribe.  He takes a wife, and believes that WW II is behind him.  Then the Japanese forces arrive near his domain.His emerald forest changes, fate forces him to revert to his military tactics to save his tribe.A British commando team discovers him and tries to get him tofight the Japanese.  Nolte will have no part in the war until itarrives at his front door.  Farewell To The King does a great job in showing the angst and sadness of joining another battle,a man torn in two by war, frustration at not being able to control the events around you.John Milius does a good job directing this picture.  It has a similarity to a David Lean picture, not unlike Bridge On The River Kwai, or Lawrence Of Arabia.  He directed previous action movies such as Red Dawn, Big Wednesday, and the first Conan feature.  This movie was better than recent WW II films that came out in the last two years.  Empire Of The Sun shows war through the eyes of a child.  Farewell To The King shows war through the eyes of a man who has been to hell and back.Thank you MGM for finally releasing this film, now, if only someone will release Boys In Company C, and Twilights' Last Gleaming.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I can honestly say that I was truly moved by this movie. It struck a cord with me that lasts to this day. This review is for the video version I taped from cable. When last I viewed this movie in 2004, it had not yet been released onto DVD. When I purchase and view the DVD I will add an addendum.Nolte, as usual was fantastic in his role as a deserter from the beaten, defeated American Army of 1942. Seeking safety in Borneo, he and his fellows land, but are captured by IJA regulars. Nolte escapes, while the others are slain by the Japanese. Nolte escapes into the tropical rainforest where after wandering for days is captured by headhunters. He manages to avoid death because of the tatoo on his chest.Later after a duel to the death he establishes himself as King of the tribe that initially captured him and forges alliances with nearby tibes in the area. But the war encroaches, and the British, in need of native assistance in their war with the Japanese, recruit Nolte's tribe. What ensues is a bloody guerilla campaign which in the end costs Nolte his wife and children and most of the surrounding villages.In the end of the movie Nolte is captured and brought to trial by the Allies for desertion. An Eddie Slovik fate awaits him. I will not reveal the end of the movie, but I will tell you that you will enjoy this unorthodox war movie and want to add it to your collection of World War II DVDs.A. Nathaniel Wallace, Jr.
summary: A Different Kind Of War Movie

reviewText: It's been more than ten year since I watch it in theaters but I still remember that they, who a war movie change my way to see this whole kind of films (maybe it was just a preview for the coming of the Terrence Malick's Masterpice The Thin Red Line).Actually it's the first time I remember watch something with Nick Nolte who later become one of my favorite actors and here there are so many reasons, specially if you feel the poetry behind one story about the search of paradise, the friendship the need to understand the true meaning of freedom.But there's more... beautifull scenes and the best soundtracks of Basil Poledouris made till now.This is not a film about war it's a legend.

reviewText: Someone reviewing this movie gave it one star and suggested that it was modeled after the hideous "Dances with Wolves" which is of course has elements of f "Little Big Man," "Dune," and "A Man called Horse."  Farewell to the King was released before "Dances with Wolves" and is an adaptation of a novel written by a Frenchman who served in Asia and was captured at Dien Bien Phu.I think of it as an attempt to combine Lawrence of Arabia and the Bridge Over the River Kwai but without David Lean's ability to display the majestic. It also has elements of the " Heart of Darkness".This movie certain has some flaws and is overblown at times but compared to the nausea inducing "Dances with Wolves" deserves an infinite number of stars.  If you think being nauseous is a polite way to express that you are nauseated then watch "Dances with Wolves."  If you still have an appreciation for drama, plot, and English then I suggest you boycott anything touched by the political correct illness that resulted in "Dances with Wolves" and then the insanity of Avatar.  Farewell to the King is not great but it is far better than most of the trivial insipid swill of Oprah land.I thought that the basis for Avatar (and the other anti-Western swill) was probably Le Guin's "The Word for World is Forest" which first appeared in Again Dangerous Visions.  I searched and found this in a WIKI article: Discussing James Cameron's movie Avatar, SF critic Gary Westfahl said that "the science fiction story that most closely resembles Avatar has to be Ursula K. Le Guin's novella The Word for World Is Forest."  While Le Guin has written some good novels, Word for World if Forest is anti-Vietnam novel only thinly disguised.Of course, I doubt that those reviewers that think Farewell to the King is an imitation of Dances with Wolves have read Le Guin. If Farewell to the King owes its origin to any popular fiction then I would suggest that it is "Heart of Darkness".Again, it is flawed but compared to Dances with Wolves, it is infinitely better.What is life without salt? Certainly the "base born children of base born beds" don't know!

reviewText: Interesting mix of reviews! If you read the 1969 novel, 'L'Adieu au Roi,' perhaps you'll have a favorable opinion . . . this is fiction, not a commentary by sociologists. The film was actually shot on location in Borneo and the scenic footage is well presented. The storyline? There was enough controversy within the studio! This isn't intended to be a WWII documentary or docudrama, it's the portrayal of the novel. Nick Nolte and cast give a terrific performancetion!It may not have done well in the boxoffice and stil it offers terrific action! To each his own . . . a good movie. Definitely recommended recommended for WWII history buffs!

reviewText: I have long been a fan of John Milius.  Unfortunately I missed this when it came out in theatrical release.  I saw the trailer but was in law school and by the time I had time to see it, it was no longer in the theaters.  Flash forward to 1995 and a girlfriend video store owner.  I was helping her close a store and saw Fairwell to the King on the shelf.  She said, "Take it if you like it."  That was the beginning of my love affair with the movie.It is definitely a man's movie, as so many of Milius's movies are.  No other director writer catchs the macho drive and male bonding that seems to fuel us men through our adolescence.Is the movie perfect?  No, but there is enough in the movie to spark memories of youthful exuberance in the most jaded male of any age.  It is the perfect beer and pretzles or beer and steak and potatos movie.It has the right balance of humor, drama and emotion.  Nolte's performance has its ups and downs and in truth there are some scenes that make me cringe, and others that make me choke up.  I challenge any man with a daughter not to get choked up in the scence where the Nolte character has to say goodbye to his.Some of the accents are a bit rough, Frank McRae as Chinga has affected a colonial english accent that is a stretch.The battle scenes are well done.  The opening and closing surf scenes are alas filmed in Hawaii.One cannot say enough about the Poledouris sound track, which I am listening too as I write this.  It is one of his best and evokes strong emotions while watching the film.The opening score with its haunting pipes, drums and violins is moving and brilliant.The battle montage with its stirring pirate like chanty melody wants you too to charge forward as Nolte yells, "Advance the colors!"This is one of the few movies I can watch over and over.All in all well worth the price and then some.  I have since retired the old VHS copy and now have a new DVD copy.Send the wife to the mall, call the guys, open some beer, put on some steaks or burgers and get ready for a jolly good romp through the last days of WWII in the Pacific.
summary: Worth the price for the soundtrack alone

reviewText: This film can be enjoyed as pure fantasy -- it's a great story and the pacing and acting are superb. It can also be viewed realistically -- the jungle settings, the natives, the British and U.S. politics -- realists can even forgive the Hollywood ending.(no spoilers!) Over the years I've found myself wondering what happened to the characters after the movie "ended." Now that's a great tale!

Being produced and directed by John Millius, it is a study in honor and integrity.  It actually has a good ending.  Nigel Haver and Frank McRae make this movie although Nick Nolte is the better known star as the indigenous force commander.  He has become King of over eight native tribes.

reviewText: The clean and charming villagers who are supposedly headhunters in Borneo are not remotely like any actual tribe. For a group of people who are cut off from "civilization", they have beautifully tailored and color-coordinated native dress, and their placid acceptance of a half-crazed white man as leader defies imagination. Nick Nolte gives a good performance as an American who flees the Army, escapes the Japanese, and finds a new life and love among natives in the mountain jungles, although his ability to learn a new language in practically no time doesn't ring true. There is a bit of humor to leaven the tale, but most of the story is about war. The score, by Basil Poledouris, is not as compelling as the one he did for "Conan the Barbarian" (also directed by Milius) but has a nice riff that is repeated rather too often. The cinematography is good, apparently shot on location, but could have been better. The settings seem more like forest than jungle, and there isn't as much sweat as one would expect in a tropical setting. This movie is enjoyable for anyone who likes action and adventure films, but because the premise is so unlikely, it's hard to take it too seriously. The plot point of a man who becomes sickened by war was done far better in "Platoon", and the end of the movie reminds me rather strongly of Tom Hanks' "Crusoe". I would call this a popcorn movie, not a classic.

reviewText: Beyond the hyperbole of other reviews (best WWII film?), there is much good to say about this messy but wonderful movie.Messy? While I love Milius' movies, one must admit they often seem to lack the production quality and polish of typical hollywood fare (the opening rowboat scene and escape while dramatic were poorly dubbed and the cinmatography seems like it could have offered more). This should be excused by the epic storytelling. Milius' movies are like garage band music that compensate in spirit what it lacks in polish.One might say this is an original story but Milius shows us it's derivitaive nature when one scene describes the narrator's adventures as akin to Conrad or Kipling. Certainly this story is cut from the same cloth as The Man Whould Would be King and Lord Jim. But somehow that still seems to qualify as original in the current Hollywood.If you are a lover of the aforementioned writers or Milius himself, or you are looking for adventure tales told well, get the DVD. I think it ranks with Big Wednesday as Milius's best movie.

reviewText: An American setting himself up as king in the middle of Borneo during WWII?  That's a bit of a stretch.  Although there was actually a white rajah of Sarawak (Borneo) at the time, who was living in exile, it is really difficult to imagine a GI fleeing the Philippines to wind up in a native paradise.  But that's Hollywood...Overall, unrealistic with good scenery, and a seemingly good ending because the bad guys lose and the good guys win.

reviewText: Here a 'deserter' finds a way of life more meaningful than that offered by 'civilization'. He is acutely aware of protocol, cruelty, the fragility of family and the inevitable extinction of value in the pursuit of pacification. It's not the greatest anti-war movie made, but it touches upon all the forgotten values of the people that we extinguish in our drive for peace and domination.

reviewText: This is one of those rare movies one can watch a number of times, and its always a spectacle! An American soldier, utilizing common-sense, flees the Philipines after its conquest by the Japanese forces in the early years of World War 2. In doing so, he avoids a miserable death in a concentration camp, as so many other allied POWs experienced. Instead, he finds himself amongst the indigenous people of Borneo, a culture of warriors and hunters, living as they did for thousands of years in the forests and mountains. They are a people whose hearts and minds yearn for an age of heroic deeds to equal that of their legendary ancestors. They live by the sword, spear, and axe, courage and valor in battle is the highest ideal. The soldier becomes a leader among them, uniting the clans, and lives in peace as the war rages abroad. However, near war's end, he and his new people collaborate with a special-operations team of allied SOE/OSS personnel, who train them to fight a guerrilla war against the remnants of Japanese forces on the island. As a result, the people are subjected to unspeakable atrocities and war-crimes...but the Japanese soldiers soon find they have subjugated a people who will take terrible revenge!
summary: This should be a classic war-film!

reviewText: Farewell to the King should have been John Milius' masterpiece. Harking back to Joseph Conrad and the days of high adventure so beloved of the writer-director, this WW2 tale of a deserter who becomes a king in Borneo only to lose everything fighting the Japanese and betrayed by the Allies, it seemed made to measure for his brand of bravado and myth making. Even had Milius not ill-advisedly taken Spielberg's advice to trim half an hour from his original cut and the film not been released in two slightly different cuts on either side of the Atlantic, Farewell would almost certainly still have been an awkward and under-achieving film so problematic are many aspects: yet for all its many faults, there's enough there that IS unique to keep on drawing me back time and again. Part old-fashioned adventure, part folie de grandeur, all box-office disaster, it's a mess, but it's an intriguing one that's hard to dislike despite its many flaws, and Basil Poledouris' remarkable score is a thing of wonder.The performances are variable: Nigel Havers is fine as the narrator who knows that one day he'll have to betray the King, but in a part that really calls for a Steve McQueen or a Russell Crowe, Nick Nolte has a few too many eccentric moments and isn't always able to make Milius' dialog sound as good as it reads (a common problem in many of his scripts). Frank McRae, Marius Weyers and Milius' old surfing buddy Gerry Lopez offer good support, but there's a truly terrible but mercifully brief performance from the future Mrs Milius, Elan Oberon. The film feels somewhat cramped at times due to Milius' decision not to shoot in Scope (he dislikes 2.35:1 despite doing his most visually impressive work in the ratio), although cinematographer Dean Semler pulls off an impressive sequence where a night time ambush goes horribly wrong due to a sudden shift in the weather.It would have been interesting to see what author Pierre Schoendoerffer would have made of it had he been able to direct it himself. Like Milius an unashamed admirer of Joseph Conrad (the story is basically a WW2 reworking of Lord Jim), the French writer-director's own films, particularly the haunting Le Crabe Tambour, hint at a more melancholy, less gung-ho attack on the material. But Milius' film has enough going for it to make it worth a look.The US cut recently released on Region 1 DVD by MGM/UA is different in quite a few ways to the European version. For a start, it's shorter, although it has some additional footage: the battle montage as the Japanese retreat is much longer (the entire battle at the river is cut from the European versions), while there's a scene of James Fox reminiscing about a girl he knew in India that is missing from the European cut, as well as a few additional lines of dialogue in some scenes. However, there is a huge and fairly important scene cut from near the end of the picture, where Fairbourne (Havers) visits the Japanese general as he has his last meal before his execution: it's not an entirely successful scene, but the film works better with it than without. There's also a big structural difference, with the US cut showing Learoyd deserting and watching his companions being executed as a pretitle sequence - this footage is in the European cut, but much more comfortably included much later when Learoyd is telling the story of how he became king. Also, the opening quote has been dropped and replaced with title cards specifying the date and location, while the closing narration is longer. On the whole, aside from the missing battle montage footage, the European version plays better.It was too much to hope for deleted scenes or even Milius' original two-and-a-half hour cut of the film on the R1 disc, but MGM/UA could have at least included the trailer - but unfortunately the disc is completely extras free. The widescreen transfer is good, but the contrast could be better in some jungle scenes. The R2 PAL discs are fullframe without any extras, but do have the European cut of the film.
summary: A sporadically glorious mess - in a slightly different cut to the European version
